Brief Hospital Course:
83 yo female with PMH of COPD, multiple sclerosis, CAD presented
with hypoxic hypercapneic respiratory distress, altered mental
status, and hypotension.

#. Respiratory distress: Worsening respiratory distress at
[**Hospital 100**] Rehab requiring non-invasive ventilation in the setting
of worsening mental status.  ABG showed acute respiratory
acidosis.  Physical exam suggests COPD flare with possible
causes including pneumonia and/or aspiration.  Mental status
changes likely due to hypercapnea.  She received nebulizers and
BiPAP in the ED with improvement.  History of CPAP/BiPAP use
suggests history of hypoventilation.  She is a definite DNI per
her daughter who is HCP.  For initial therapy was treated with
Methylprednisolone 125 mg IV TID and broad spectrum antibiotics
for possible pneumonia including Vancomycin / Levofloxacin /
Flagyl.  She improved rapidly within hours of being in the ICU
which was more suggestive of an aspiration event with subsequent
pneumonitis.  Her steroids were rapidly tapered on day #2 to
Prednisone 40 mg with plan to taper over the following 3 days.
Flagyl was also discontinued [**2104-6-24**] and vanco was discontinued
on [**6-25**] after speciation of GPC in blood culture from [**6-22**] as
coag-neagtive staph.  Levofloxacin was continued for planned 5
day course. Rapid viral testing and urine Legionella were
negative.  She was continued on nebulizers both standing and as
needed, and received cough syrup and benzonate for cough.

#. Hypotension: Concerning for infectious etiology with
distributive shock.  She met SIRS criteria for RR, HR, and
leukocytosis.  She received IVF in the ED but required
peripheral Levophed.  Volume status was difficult to assess
clinically.  She had no central access, but the family would
allow it in the future if we felt it was appropriate and
indicated.  Arterial line was placed and SBP rapidly improved to
SBP 120s.  Central access was ultimatley not needed.  She was
continued on Levofloxacin for possible pneumonia with planned
course of 5 days.  She was also continued on Vancomycin until
[**6-25**] when speciation of positive blood culture from [**6-22**] appeared
to be a contaminant.

#. Altered mental status:  Upon admission was noted to have
mental status changes in the setting of possible infection and
hypoxemia.  Treated with antibiotics.  Improvement with BIPAP
also suggests hypercapnea, though no ABG was drawn upon arrival.
 Other etiology could include seizure given history of seizure
disorder on Dilantin, though no report of seizure activity.
Dilantin level low but did not adjust given no known seizure for
20 years and rapid improvement with BiPAP and antibiotics.

#. COPD:  Treated with steroids, antibiotics and nebulizers as
above.

#. Seizure disorder:  Reportedly no seizures for decades, though
mental status changes upon arrival.  Dilantin level low but did
not change dosing given low suspicion for seizure.  Dosed
Dilantin 100 mg [**Hospital1 **] rather than 200 mg daily per pharmacy
recommendations.

#. Troponin elevation (NSTEMI): Patient with elevated troponin
the day of admission.  This was thought to be due to demand
ischemia given her respiratory decompensation.  Troponins were
quickly downward trending.  She was continued on her home
simvastatin, and aspirin was increased to full dose of 325 mg PO
daily. She should follow up with her PCP to discuss increased
dose of statin (likely indicated if tolerated) and beta blocker
(possibly beneficial if able to tolerate in setting of known
COPD).

#. CAD: Continued on statin and full dose aspirin as above.

#. Multiple Sclerosis: No current active problems.

#. Hypothyroid: Continued on Synthroid.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. [**Known lastname **] is a 70 year old woman with a history of Multiple
sclerosis, DM, HTN, and frequent UTIs due to a chronic
indwelling Foley catheter who presented with a presumed
urosepsis.
.
1. Urosepsis:
She has a history of chronic UTIs, up to twice per month that
are thought to be due to her indwelling Foley catheter.  She has
had a foley catheter for several years and has it changed once
per month by her home health aide.  On admission she had stable
hemodynamics but had an elevated lactate and was admitted to the
ICU under the sepsis protocol.  Her hemodynamics remained stable
and her lactate trended down and she was quickly transferred to
the medical floor.  Her urine culture eventually grew positive
for a highly resistant strain of Klebsiella pneumonia. In
consultation with the ID service, she was treated with
ceftriaxone for six days and meropenem for four days.  In
addition, abdominal CT scans were performed which did not reveal
any anatomic abnormality in the urinary tract or any evidence of
pyelonephritis (the suspicion of pyelonephritis seen on the [**11-10**]
study was thought to be due to artifact).  She thus completed a
10 day course of IV antibiotics and was not discharged on any
antibiotic prophylaxis as she has a history of highly resistant
organisms.  She should have her Foley catheter changed weekly
under sterile conditions to try to prevent future urinary tract
infections.
.
2. Delirium:
In the middle of her hospitalization she was noted to become
agitated and delirious alternating between becoming quite
somnolent and delirious with confusion, agitation, and
perseveration.  She was so delirious that she required
intubation to perform CT scans.  Evaluation of this included a
negative EEG, a negative head CT, a negative CXR, an abdominal
CT negative for an intra-abdominal infection, and normal labs
(CBC and electrolytes).  In addition repeat urine and blood
cultures were negative.  All of her psychotropic medications
were held including ativan and any sleeping agents such as
ambien or trazodone and she was weaned off of her paxil.
Eventually her mental status cleared and she was again alert and
oriented, conversant, and able to follow directions.  Thus it
was thought that her delirium was most likely medication
induced.  At discharge, she was maintained on her multiple
sclerosis meds but was not on paxil or ativan.
.
3. Diabetes mellitus:
She was maintained on her home regimen of 75/25 and glyburide.
Her metformin was held initially due to an elevated creatinine
and was not restarted during her hospitalization.  Her blood
sugars ranged during her stay depending on her po intake but
over the several days preceding her discharge her blood sugars
were around 100.  She was discharged on the following regimen.
75/25 18 units with breakfast and 20 units with dinner and
glyburide 5 mg twice daily.  This regimen may need to be altered
depending on her po intake.  She is also completing a prednisone
taper (finished [**2119-11-13**]) which may cause her blood sugars to
decrease somewhat.

4. Bullous pemphigoid:
She was seen by the dermatology service while hospitalized and a
punch biopsy was consistent with bullous pemphigoid.  She was
continued on her prednisone taper (finished [**2119-11-13**]) and was
also given topical clobetasol 0.05% cream twice daily.  On this
regimen her blisters and erosions over her bilateral knees
slowly began to resolve.  They did not disappear completely and
if there is further concern, her outside dermatologist should be
contact[**Name (NI) **] (Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 98283**] of [**Hospital1 **] [**Name (NI) 47**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 98284**]).
.
5. Multiple sclerosis:
She was continued on her outpatient regimen of carbamazepine,
gabapentin, and baclofen.
.
6. Hypothyroid: cont levoxyl
.
7. Ppx: SQ heparin, PPI, ASA
.
8. Code: full
.
9. Comm: daughter
.
10. Access: right IJ
.
11. Dispo: To Skilled Nursing Facility

Brief Hospital Course:
66 year old male with history of MS, suprapubic catheter
w/recurrent UTIs presenting with lethagy and anuria.  On
admission, the patient had a leukocytosis to 19, tachycardia,
hypotension and he was admitted to the MICU.  He was started on
IV linezolid/meropenem.  He was seen by urology who relieved a
SPT obstruction after which he had good urine output.  His
condition improved with IV fluids and antibiotics and he was
transferred to the floor. On the floor, he remained afebrile
without leukocytosis.  A blood culture from [**1-30**] (1 of 2) was
positive for coag negative staph which was felt to be a
contamination. His urine culture was also contaminated and
therefore not speciated.  Subsequent urine cultures were
negative.  He will be discharged on a total 14 day course of
antibiotics (PO linezolid and IV ertapenem) for presumed
urosepsis.  Other issues during his admission includes anemia
with iron studies suggesting anemia of chronic disease.  He also
presented with acute kidney injury which resolved with IVF.  His
electrolytes were repleted prn and was notable for low phos
which returned to [**Location 213**] with IV repletion.  A PTH was chacked
to look for primary or secondary hyperparathyroid, but this was
pending prior to discharge.  We would recommend follow-up of his
phos by his PCP in addition to checking vitamin D levels.  He
also did have some loose stools and C diff was negative.  His
bowel regimen was held during most of his hospitalization.  In
regards to MS and his other chronic medical issues, his home
medications were continued.  As a side note, pleural effusions
and LLL consolidation were noted on CXR and were determined to
be stable compared to prior films.  These findings have been
present since at least [**2171**] and per his PCP are likely secondary
to chronic atelectasis.

Brief Hospital Course:
66 year old male with history of MS, suprapubic catheter
presents for admission after being found to have a positive
blood culture after being discharged from hospitalization for
sepsis of unidentified source.
.
During his first hospital course, no organism had been
identified and the patient appeared clinically well with no
fevers or white count.  He was originally discharged on
linezolid and meropenem for broad empiric coverage given history
of resistant bugs in the past. He had had one set blood cx
positive for coag-negative GPC which was presmued to be a
contaminant. However, when a second BCx (from [**2-2**]) returned
positive with a similar profile shortly after discharge, he was
readmitted for further work-up. ID was consulted, and they
recommended changing his antibiotic course to vancomycin and
meropenem. He continued to appear clinically well with no fevers
or leukocytosis and surveillance blood cultures were negative.
He underwent a TTE to r/o endocarditis but the image quality was
poor.  A TEE was attempted but the patient did not tolerate the

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 49 year old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis
and recurrent UTI's with [**Month/Year (2) 45862**] catheter who presented with
fever and mental status change.  Patient was admitted to the
[**Hospital Ward Name 332**] Intensive Care Unit.  Short [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] stay for sepsis protocol
involved rescucitation with IVF, no pressors and initiation of
Zosyn/Vancomycin.  The following issues were addressed on this
admission:
.
1) Concerning Fevers, Mental Status Change: Patient admitted
with fevers to 102 and history of urinary tract infections
([**Hospital Unit Name 45862**] catheter) from multi-drug resistant organisms
including psuedomonas and MRSA. Likely sources of infection
included urine and or foot ulcers given history and exam.  As
per ICU team, although patient with leukocytosis, tachycardia,
and hyperthermia, she was never hypotensive and lactate was <4.
History of multiple prior UTI's however, did not notice her
usual symptoms, no purulent drainage form [**Hospital Unit Name 45862**] tube which
was due to be changed but urine grew both pseudomonas and MRSA.
The patient also reported recent history of trauma to foot
ulcers, swabs growing lots of bacteria but are of unclear value.
 Reportedly with purulent drainage, fluctuance induration at
home, but on exam here, no evidence of osteomyletis.  Foot films
were negative for evidence of bone infection.  Patient had
ultrasound for suspicious looking area of fluctuance of fifth
left toe.  Ultrasound showed no evidence of abcess. Exam
consistent with possible cellulitis.  There were no other
localizing sources of infection on history/exam.   No evidence
pneumonia, abdominal or other source at this time. No evidence
of meningismus to suggest meningitis/encephalitis.  Chest x-ray
was without acute process.  Blood cultures remained negative as
of date of discharge.
Patient maintained on zosyn/vancomycin.  She will be treated
with 14 day course of each to cover urinary tract infection
secondary to pseudomonas and MRSA and possible cellulitis.
Final blood culture results pending at time of discharge.
Altered mental status returned to baseline over [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] course with
treatment of infection and IV fluids.

2)Concerning multiple sclerosis: Patient was maintained on
baclofen, gabapentin, glatiramer; prednisone (got stress dose in
ER given relative hypotension). [**Name2 (NI) **] acute issues. On alendronate
given long-term steroids, dosing q Thursday.
*
3) Prophylaxis: Patient maintained on subcutaneous heparin for
DVT prophylaxis and  famotidine (given steroids) for GI
prophylaxis.

4) Pain: Percocet was maintained on her home dosing for foot
pain.
*
5) Code: Patient full code throughout admission.

Patient was a candidate for rehabilitation but did not desire
rehab at this time, wanted to be discharged to home.
*

Brief Hospital Course:
Assessment and Plan: 74 yoM w/ a h/o MS, PE, and syncope
presents with hypotension and found to have UTI.

1. Hypotension/UTI:  Likely due to urosepsis. The patient's
blood pressure responded nicely to IV fluids in the ICU.  His
chronic bradycardia probably contributed to the overall picture
and inability to compensate.  His antihypertensives were
initially held and he was restarted on amlodipine and enalapril
prior to discharge.  He was treated with meropenem (given his
history of ESBL Klebsiella) for his UTI which was changed to
ertapenem at the time of discharge.  His suprapubic catheter was
changed.

2. Non responsiveness: He has a long history of vasovagal
syncope and has had multiple outpatient studies to work this up.
 This episode was unlikely a syncopal event given the duration
that he was non responsive. He had no witnessed seizure
activity.  This episode was more likely due to global cerebral
hypoperfusion in the setting of hypotension / UTI.  We discussed
at length that his family should bring him immediately to the ED
if he has an event like this in the future.  Pt to have
outpatient cognitive screening.

3. Bradycardia: Was seen by EP last year for recurrent syncopal
episodes, hypertension, and prolonged PR interval his syncope
was determined to be likely vasovagal given his prodrome of
diaphoresis, fatigue, and nausea.

4. Multiple sclerosis:  continued his home baclofen, enablex,
neurontin, methylphenidate, and remeron.  Has chronic
constipation and was continued on his bowel regimen.

5. Hypercholesterolemia: His statin was held due to an increased
Ck which trended down during his admission.  He should discuss
with his PCP whether to restart his statin.

6. Hyponatremia: Likely hypovolemic hyponatremia and responded
to hydration.

7. Renal failure: Cr 1.3 at admission and normalized during his
admission.

8. Ppx: heparin sc tid, bowel regimen prn, PPI blocker.

9. Full code

Brief Hospital Course:
76 year old male with MS, h/o sinus bradycardia and dx of
vasovagal syncope who prsents with two days of unresponsiveness.

with another episode of unresponsiveness in the setting of
bradycardia (30s bpm) and hypotension (SBP 70s).  EKG showed
only sinus bradycardia.  He was volume resucitated, started on
Meropenem for h/o ESBL UTI, and was about to be intubated due to
concern for inability ot protect his airway.  Suddenly he awoke
with clear consciousness and stated that he was having a vagal
episode.  Neurology was consulted about this "vagal episode".
High concern was given to the likelyhood of non convulsive
seizures.  After his arousal his hemodynamic status had improved
and he was called out to the floor.  He underwent a 24 hours EEG
while in the hospital, which showed no signs of seizure.  Some
of his medications were adjusted with the question about timolol
having systemic effect and discontinuation of gabapention.  The
most likely cause of his altered mental status is likely due to
autonomic dysfunction and hypoperfusion in the setting of
dehydration and UTI.  This however should be followed up by his
primary care physician, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] cardiologist, and his
ophthalmologist.
.
#. Labile blood pressure: Hypotension & Hypertension.
Hypotension at the initial presentation is likely due to
hypovolemia given pre-renal state.  It improved with hydration.
However, given that he has MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) 5348**], likely has some
autonomic dysfuction, and post hydration, his SBP was elevated
up to the 180s.  In addition to the increase in lisinopril from
10 mg to 20 mg, he also received an additional dose of
hydralazine IV.  His BP improved from these measures, and he is
to go home on home medication given prior history of
hypotension.  This should be followed up by his primary care
doctor.
.

admission as a part of the AMS work-up.  He was started on
meropenem [**2153-8-9**] initially given hsitory of ESBL UTI.  As the
culture grew out sensitive E. Coli, he was switched to Keflex
because of sensitivity to cefazolin on [**2153-8-11**].  The plan was
to complete a 10 day course of antibiotics on [**2153-8-17**].  This
can be followed up by his primary care provider.
.
#. Acute renal failure.  Patient initally presented elevated Crt
1.6 with [**Year (4 digits) 5348**] of 0.8-1.0.  He was fluid resuscitated in the
MICU, and his Crt returned to [**Year (4 digits) 5348**] on [**2153-8-10**].
.

.

Brief Hospital Course:
46-year-old female with severe multiple sclerosis admitted to
MICU with hypoxia secondary to aspiration pneumonitis with
subsequent PEG placement and discussion with husband about
hospice.

# Aspiration with hypoxic respiratory distress
Likely from aspiration event on top of prior pneumonia. Patient
initially hypoxic to the high 80's which improved on oxygen.
Intubation not required. Clinical history of acute onset
(~30min) more consistent with aspiration rather than worsening
of pneumonia.  CT findings suggesting aspiration pneumonitis.
Patient recently hospitalized for pneumonia at [**Hospital3 2358**].
Other possibilities include PE (ruled out on CT) or worsening of
her MS though the acuity makes this unlikely. She was initially
treated with vancomycin, cefepime, levofloxacin. After
resolution of hypoxia, patient called out to floor and weaned
from O2 with no further issues. Antibiotic coverage was narrowed
to a 7-day course of levaquin/flagyl. Repeat CXR showed no
apparent infiltrate or worsening lung disease. Blood, sputum
cultures were negative. Remained afebrile and hemodynamically
stable. Given [**Hospital3 16169**] aspiration, multiple failed
speech/swallow evaluation, and difficulty managing secretions,
she was made NPO with dobhoff tube feeds. PEG tube was
subsequently placed after discussion with husband. [**Name (NI) **]
subsequently tolerated tube feeds well and was discharged.

# Chronic Severe Multiple Sclerosis: Patient is followed by
[**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 730**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **]. Her MS medications were held or given at lower
dose given concern for altered sensorium and further aspiration
events. She was discharged on reduced dosage of gabapentin and
baclofen along with fluoxetine, oxycodone prn, tizanidine, and
ritalin.

Given end-stage MS, it was discussed with her husband about
hospice after Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] suggested this possibility. Palliative
care consult discussed with husband for further outpatient
consideration.

# Anemia
Patient had admission Hct 42.7 with discharge Hct 32.8. Minimal
blood loss per IR from PEG placement. Stools were hemoccult
negative. Etiology unknown but Hct stable at discharge. DDx
includes phlebotomy, critical illness, or poor nutrition with
marrow suppressive effect.

Advise outpatient Hct check to see if continues to stabilize.

# Sacral Decubitus Ulcer:
Patient has had long standing wound vac. Wound care consulted
for management and recommended pressure relief, frequent
repositioning. There were no signs of infection.

# Yeast on UA
Patient had UA with > 100,000 organisms/mL of yeast. Given
multiple sclerosis and likely functional bladder issues, concern
for colonization given foley vs. infection. Patient was afebrile
with no irritative symptoms. Renal US obtained to rule out upper
tract disease and was negative. Foley subsequently changed.

# Access
The patient lost access in the ICU with subsequent PICC placed
by IR for antibiotics. PICC line discontinued at discharge as no
further need for antibiotics.

# Code status: Full code, discuss further on outpatient basis.

Brief Hospital Course:
71 yo M s/p trach/peg who presents from LTAC with fever, cough,
and abdominal pain.

1. Respiratory Failure: Fever, leukocytosis, and CXR findings
supportive of a multifocal, vent-associated pneumonia; also with
right middle lobe collapse, bilateral effusions, and worsening
pulmonary edema. He was maintained on CPAP and started on
vancomycin and cefepime. Patient still with fevers to 102 prior
to discharge so started on standing Tylenol tid, but WBC slowly
improving on discharge. His lasix was initially held but
restarted at home dose of 20 mg IV bid on discharge.
* Plan for 8-day course of vancomycin and cefepime; last dose on
[**5-17**].
* Check vancomycin trough at 7pm on [**5-11**] and as needed
thereafter
* Follow up pending sputum (gram neg rods on stain), blood, and
urine cultures
* Adjust lasix dose as indicated

2. Colitis: Pt with a history of C. diff. He was empirically
started on flagyl and po vancomycin on [**5-9**] at [**Hospital 100**] Rehab.
Here, he was initially continued on po vancomycin. However, CT
abdomen showed mild resolving colitis, and C. diff toxins
returned negative, so po vancomycin was stopped on day of
discharge.

3. Scrotal swelling/tenderness: Scrotal ultrasound unremarkable
with absent venous waveform but normal arterial inflow. Urology
consult felt this was not consistent with testicular torsion and
highly unlikely given age and bilateral presentation. [**Month (only) 116**]
represent a mild orchitis; scrotal elevation and
anti-inflammatories recommended. Potential infection would be
treated with his current antibiotic regimen for pneumonia.

4. Positive troponin: Mildly elevated on presentation but
patient without chest pain. Repeat troponin was flat, ruling out
MI. This likely represented mild demand in the setting of
infection. He was continued on his ASA and beta blocker.

5. Hypertension: Continued on outpatient amlodipine, metoprolol,
and lisinopril. Lasix restarted prior to discharge. Hydralazine
was discontinued.

6. Anemia: Hct remained stable in 27 to 30 range.

7. Depression: Continued citalopram.

8. Gout: Continued allopurinol.

9. Hypothyroid: Continued levothyroxine.

10. H/o GI Bleed: Continued sucralfate and omeprazole.

11. Incidental finding: CT Abd/pelvis showed "several
indeterminate renal cysts."
* Ultrasound recommended for better evaluation.

12. Code status: Pt confirmed full code with alternate HCP (son)
present.

History of Present Illness:
62 yo female with pmhx sig for multiple sclerosis, hypertension,
seizures, and frequent UTIs, who presents to ED via ambulance
with fever to 105 and tachycardia. Pt is somewhat of a poor
historian as she is post-op on arrival to the ICU, but is able
to state that she called the ambulance after she began feeling
"so hot". She denies any recent cough, dysuria, diarrhea, no
sick contacts, no recent travel; last hospitalization
approximately one month ago for MS exacerbation.
.
On arrival to the ED, she was tachycardic to the 140's, and
febrile to 105. Chest x-ray and UA were unremarkable, blood
cultures were drawn, lactate found to be 3.5. The patient had a
left SC port-a-cath that had been placed in [**2139**] for better
access for IV steroid requirements during her MS flares. This
was thought to be the likely source of infection, and surgery
was consulted. It was decided to take her to the OR for removal
of the catheter. Clear fluid drained from the cath, no frank pus
noted. Cultures of the fluid were sent and the cath tip sent for
culture. She was given a dose of Vancomycin and Levofloxacin
along with 3 liters IVF in the ED, and admitted to the MICU for
further management. A code sepsis was not called, as the patient
never became hypotensive.
.
On arrival to the ICU, the patient is alert and oriented x 3,
complaining of muscle spasms (chronic) in her legs. She denies
any other pain, no dyspnea. All other ROS negative.

A/P: 62 yo female with history of MS, seizures, htn, urinary
infections who is admitted to ICU for fever and tachycardia.
.

to be most likely [**2-19**] to port-a-cath.  The port was removed by
surgery on the day of admission.  Hypotension resolved with
fluid boluses, and pt did not require any pressors.  Cultures
grew pansensitive pseudomonas. Pt was initially started on
Vancomycin and Levo changed to Ciprofloxacin and Ceftazidime
after culture data returned; Pt was afebrile for 72 hours before
discharge. She was hemodynamically stable throughout her stay on
the regular medical floor. A PICC line was placed for long term
antibiotic treatment(2 week course), pt was discharged with VNA
for IV services.
.

followed by endocrinology outpatient. Resolved with IVF and
continued on vitamin D; phosphate was repleted. Stable during
this admission.
.

.

reports fall at home three days ago. EKG shows non-specific ST
depressions, likely rate related, repeat cardiac enzymes were
negative
.

and lopressor in setting of infection; restarted after
port-a-cath removal and 24 hours stability on regular medical
floor.
.

during this admission.
.
# MS- stable during this admission.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 70yoM with h/o multiple sclerosis, recent PNA,
recurrent UTI, who presents with fever, urinary tract infection
and acute renal failure, later found to have strep milleri
empyema.
.
# Urinary tract infection, w/ urosepsis: initially presented
febrile and hypotensive to 80's. He was initially in the MICU,
but responded very well to IVF, so was called out after 24
hours. He grew resistant proteus, and was started on meropenem.
He was initially to complete a 2 week course, but then empyema
was found so course of meropenem extended to 28 days minimum. A
PICC line was inserted on [**3-8**]. While on meropenem, should check
weekly CBC with dif, BUN, Creatinine, and LFTs
.
# Empyema: Likely related to PNA [**1-4**] prior to admission at [**Hospital1 2025**].
A thoracentesis was done, with chest tube left in place. Fluid
was grossly purulent, consistent with empyema. The empyema
eventually grew strep milleri. After 48 hours after admission.
he was afebrile and breathing well for rest of admission. CT
scan on [**3-10**] suggested trapped lung. Thoracic surgery consulted
and felt that decortication was not warranted, recommended that
the chest tube stay in place for at least 3 weeks, w/ thoracic
surgery follow-up at that time. TPA/DNase x2 was used to get out
residual empyema. Will continue extended course of meropenem as
well. At rehab, chest tube should be flushed w/ 20cc normal
saline 2-3 times daily. It should be to bulb suction or water
seal. He should have a repeat chest CT scan w/ IV contrast in 3
weeks
.
# Acute kidney injury: Admission creatinine was 5.1, from a
normal baseline. Likely was ATN from diarrhea/dehydration, and
pt also has ibuprofen 800mg TID listed on home meds. Was given
IVF, diarrhea resolved, and NSAIDs were held. His creatinine
returned to baseline of 0.9 upon discharge. NSAIDS should
continue to be held.
.
# Diarrhea: Now resolved. c dif negative, likely viral illness.
No abd pain or N/V.
.
# Multiple sclerosis: per NH records, has been getting tylenol.
Written for opiate but not regularly receiving. Continued that
therapy in house, and also oxybutynin.
.
# Depression/Anxiety: Continued mirtazepine, trazadone, and
klonopin. Pt declined seeing SW or psychiatry. His affect is
very flat.
.
# Hyperlipidemia - simvastatin was decreased to 40 mg due to
black box warning on simvastatin 80 mg. LDL is <50 this
admission, so will permanently change simva to 40mg daily.
.
# CAD s/p CABG [**2184**]: continued aspirin and statin (at lower
dose)
.
# COPD on 2L O2 baseline: continued advair and spiriva with prn
albuterol.
.
# OSA: on bipap at home, but refused in house.
.
# GERD: continued PPI and H2 blocker.  Decrease PPI as no
symptoms, and did not want to overdose w/ PPI's
.
# H/o prostate ca s/p XRT: continued flomax.
.
# Mild aortic stenosis: will need to be followed long term
.

The pt is a 64 year-old man with PMHx of IDDM, Multiple
Sclerosis
and longterm tobacco abuse who presents with slurred speech and
worsened R-sided weakness, and was found at an OSH to have a
2.5cm pontine hemorrhage.
The hx was obtained mostly from pt's wife.  She reports that at
baseline the patient has weakness from his MS of his R leg, most
notable for a R foot drop as well as weakness of his R hand, of
which he can only use his 1st digit and thumb, and the other are
"always closed in a fist".  He uses a walker to get around.
However, this morning he woke up and was slurring his speech,
which is unusual for him unless his blood sugar is too low.  She
checked his blood sugar and it was 30.  She gave him glucose and
[**Location (un) 2452**] juice and unlike other times it has been too low, his
slurred speech didn't improve.  In addition, she noticed that
his
R face was drooping and his R eye was at first "too open" and
then the eyelid was droopy.  She called 911 and he was taken to
[**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], where a CT scan showed a 2.5cm pontine hemorrhage.

He was then sent to us for further evaluation.  Of note, he was
note noted to be hypertensive at [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], with BP max
recorded in the 150's.  He does not have hypertension at
baseline.
When he arrived in our ED, his BP was in the 130's and he was
taken to a repeat CT scan, which showed an essentially unchanged
hemorrhage in the pons.  He was seen by neurosurgery who felt
that the bleed was too deep to intervene surgically at this
point.  His initial neurological exam showed essentially full
eye
movements and then a repeat exam 1 hour later showed inability
to
look horizontally and difficulty with downward gaze L > R.
Therefore, given the changing exam and the location of his bleed
he was admitted to the ICU for closer monitoring.

worsened right sided weakness, but denies loss of vision,

parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention.

Brief Hospital Course:
1.  NEURO - The patient arrived intubated with a non-focal exam,
but with bilateral upgoing toes and only sparse medical history.
A NCHCT revealed no bleed. An MRI the next day revealed
extensive white matter disease, with a maximum around the corpus
callosum. There are no data to suggest CADASIL: No microbleeds
on GRE, no temporal [**Doctor Last Name 534**] involvement of the WN lesions, no
family history. Tox-screen and basic screening labs including
U/A were negative.

Depakote level was 44 ug/mL, non-trough. She was bolused with
VPA twice over the next 24 hours, as her repeat level remained
44. Of note, the values of VPA have been as high as 129, but
none of the levels is a "true trough". Her maintenance dose was
increased to a total of 2500 mg QD, divided in 3 IV doses in the
ICU but switched to [**Hospital1 **] PO on transfer to floor. LFTs were
normal.

There was no further seizure activity. She had an EEG done which
showed semirhythmic theta range activity with occasional sharp
waves in the R anterior temporal region, and a disorganized, low
voltage BG with a 6 Hz posterior dominant rhythm.

Clinically she woke up slowly over the course of 3 days in the
ICU. Her prolonged recovery time is not surprising given the
prolonged seizure, the limited cerebral reserves at baseline and
the benzodiazepines she received.  She returned to her baseline
the day after transfer without any further concerns.  A repeat
Depakote level was 122 with goal of >80.  It was felt that she
was too sedated on this Depakote dose (1250mg [**Hospital1 **]) and therefore
was decreased back to 1000mg [**Hospital1 **] as her status epilepticus was
likely triggered by her acute pneumonia.

2.  RESP - She was noted to have a pneumonia while on the
respirator, with a suspicion of aspiration. She spiked high
fever and CXR confirmed a RLL infiltrate. She was started on
Piperacillin-Tazobactam Na 4.5g IV Q8H and Vancomycin 1000mg
Q12H on [**2171-5-28**]. She was remained in the ICU one day
post-extubation due to excessive suctioning requirements. She
was weaned quickly to room air which she remained at upon
discharge.

3.  ID - Pneumonia as above. She had a fever on admission and
was given Ceftriaxone 2 grams x 1 and Vancomycin 1 gram x 1, as
well as Ampicillin 2 grams IV x 1 and Acyclovir 800 mg IV x 1 -
per ED clinician order sheet in chart.  LP on admission was
sterile including Gram stain, culture no growth.  A blood
culture on [**2171-5-25**] grew coagulase negative staph with repeat
negative x 3.  Two respiratory cultures grew only normal flora.

Brief Hospital Course:
64 y.o. woman with advanced MS, schizophrenia, dementia,
dysphagia  who came in from [**Hospital1 1501**] on [**2174-9-24**] with resp distress,
fevers, found to be in septic shock due to Right middle lobe
pneumonia from a possible aspiration.  She was intubated on
presentation, extubated [**2174-9-27**] and transferred to the floor on
[**2174-9-30**] on RA, reintubated on [**2174-10-8**] and extubated [**2174-10-11**],
transferred back to the floor on [**2174-10-12**].  Her course was
complicated by [**Last Name (un) **] (thought to be secondary to ATN) - this
ultimately resolved.
.
#HCAP/ GNR bacteremia -The patient presented with respiratory
failure requiring intubation and was treated for pneumonia with
vancomycin and zosyn.  She was pressors while in the ICU but was
weaned off. Pt completed a 7 day course of vanc/zosyn but on
[**10-1**] she had a fever of 101.1 with blood cultures from the PICC
line growing GNR - picc removed, tip cultured negative.
Pneumonia felt to be likely source. Urine cultures showed only
fecal contamination.  Sputum cultures did not show any specific
organism for the pneumonia.  Blood cultures grew Pseudomonas and
Klebsiella, initially started on Meropenem, but then switched to
Tobramycin and Cefepime after the sensitivies returned and
Infectious Disease was consulted.  She had a new PICC placed and
will need to have 14 day courses of Tobramycin ([**Date range (1) 96358**]) for
blood stream infection and Cefepime for HCAP/VAP ([**Date range (1) 96359**]).
Given her thick secretions, she has been started on a
scopolamine patch with good effect.  She is currently stable on
room air.
The [**Hospital 228**] health care proxy, [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) **], is aware that pt
is at high risk for recurrent episodes of aspiration and that
the patient may benefit from tracheostomy.  The ICU team
discussed this extensively with the HCP, however, at this time,
she is deferring this option.  This is partly because the
patient's son is also a HCP for the pt, but is currently serving
in the Army in [**Country 2451**], and is not available to participate in the
discussion.
.
#HTN:The patient was initially hypotensive on pressors but then
was weaned off and subsequently restarted on her Metoprolol at
higher dose to avoid her ACEI due to [**Last Name (un) **]. She was restarted
lisinopril at 5 mg po daily when her Cr normalized but Cr rose
slightly so it was d/ced and metoprolol was uptitrated.  She
briefly required the addition of amlodipine 5 mg for BP control.
 Her hypertension is currently well controlled with metoprolol
only.
.
#[**Last Name (un) **]: It was initially felt to be likely ATN. Creatinine
downtrended to 1.1 with IVF.  It rose slightly with reinitiation
of her ACE-I, so it has been discontinued indefinitely until she
is followed-up as an outpatient.  She maintained good output and
is incontinent at baseline.  Random bladder scan showed only 130
ml residual.  Her BUN/Cr should continue to be monitored,
especially since she is on Tobramycin which has nephrotoxicity.
If her renal function declines, she will need her Tobramycin
levels checked for possible dosing readjustment.
.
#GI bleed: The patient was noted to have a small amt coffee
ground emesis in ED which cleared w/ 100 cc lavage. It was
presumed stress gastritis and she was placed on a PPI.  Her
hematocrit did downtrend to 20.9, but she responded
appropriately to 1 unit PRBC blood transfusion and has remained
stable since.  A CT chest/abdomen/pelvis did not show any source
of active bleeding.
.
#Seizure disorder: The patient has a history of seizures in the
setting of sepsis. Although there was a question of seizure like
activity at admission, she had no further episodes after
extubation and was continued on her Depakote.  Neurology was
consulted, they did not think she was having breakthrough
seizures.  They did increase her Depakote dose after levels were
low, likely due to interaction with Meropenem.  Her goal
Depakote levels are 50 - 60, and she will require repeat blood
levels.  She had a bedside EEG that on prelim read shows no
status epilepticus.
.
#DM: Given her [**Last Name (un) **], metformin was discontinued and she is being
treated with a Lispro sliding scale.
.
#FEN:The patient was restarted on her tube feeds for a goal of
60ml/hr of Promote with fiber at 20 hrs/day.  However, it was
changed to Glucerna with beneprotein as she had elevated blood
sugars.
.
#Access: She initially had a central line in the ICU and had a
PICC line placed.  When bacteremic, the PICC line was d/ced and
a new central line was placed on [**10-2**], and this was ultimately
removed and new PICC ([**10-7**]) placed after being surveillance
culture negative for 72 hours.
.

Ms. [**Known lastname **] is a 64-year-old female with a history of advanced MS

subtheraputic depakote level.

subtherapeutic valproate level on admission (35) and systemic
inflammatory syndrome from a UTI.  These seizures were broken
with ativan and pt was placed on depakote and keppra per neuro.
Patient was supratheraputic on depakote on discharge (125).  She
was seizure free for the remainder of the hospitalization.

# UTI/SIRS: On admission pt met criteria for SIRS with a fever,
sinus tachycardia, leukocytosis to 16.9 and a PMN predominance.
Potential etiolgies included a urinary source as well as [**3-9**]
seizure.  Patient was aggressively hydrated with NS ~4L to
resolve tachycardia.  Initially her UTI was covered with
cefepime and tobramycin given her recent history of resistant
klebsiella and pseudomonas blood infections a month ago of
unclear source.  Urine culture was positive for VRE.  Patient
was sent to her [**Hospital1 1501**] with Linezolid 600mg [**Hospital1 **] for 10 days through
[**2174-11-14**].

desaturations. Her CXR appeared to be without parenchymal
disease though ?atelectasis vs infiltrate in [**Last Name (LF) 25730**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] her
desaturations may have been a sedative effect from ativan.  She
also had a history of desaturating from mucous plugging.  While
patien has copious secretions during the remainder of her
hospitalization, with aggressive suctioning she have good oxygen
saturations on room air.

to be high.

# HTN: continue metoprolol 100mg [**Hospital1 **]

Brief Hospital Course:
64F with MMP presented to the hospital because G-tube fell out,
found to have hypotension and fever concerning for sepsis.

ACTIVE ISSUES:

# sepsis/hypotension:  blood cultures still pending so unsure if
pt was truly septic or if she was hypotensive for other reasons.
 Pt was febrile on admission and had also lost G-tube access and
so had poor po intake prior to admission.  Hypotension could be
multifactorial secondary to volume depletion, febrile
vasodilatation, or infection.  U/A was dirty on admission and pt
has chronic foley placement.  However, UCx was negative.  Also
found to have right lower lobe infiltrate on CXR concerning for
pneumonia.  Gave pt tylenol and 2 liters of fluid rescucitation
in ED.  Hypotension and fevers subsequently resolved and she was
normotensive and afebrile by the time she reached MICU floor and
remained so throughout hospital course.  Treated pt empirically
initially with linezolid/cefepime/tobra because of her history
of resistant UTIs.  However, palliative care was consulted and
confirmed that patient had been made DNR/DNI in the past with
comfort measures only and plan was to only return to hospital
for g-tube replacement.  Therefore, IV antibiotics were stopped
and pt was given prescription for oral cefpodoxime for total 5
day course to treat infection with plans to not treat or
hospitalize should infection recur.

# nutrition/G-tube - replaced G-tube by IR while in house and
resumed tube feeds and po meds.

# comfort care: Per above, pt is comfort measures only with no
plans for further hospitalization.  Adjusted patient's home
medications upon discharge as follows: stopped simvastatin for
CAD/HLD; stopped heparin for DVT ppx; stopped Vit. C,
multivitamin, and Vit. D; stopped Amlodipine and Lisinopril for
hypertension; stopped [**Month/Day (2) **] for infection prophylaxis

INACTIVE ISSUES:

#  Seizure d/o - gave home seizure meds by IV while awaiting
g-tube replacement.  After placement, switched back to po meds.
Will continue for comfort.

# diabetes: continued pt on SSI.  will continue insulin glargine
and insulin lispro as outpatient

# COPD: continued ipratropium, albuterol nebs

echocardiogram did not reveal wall motion abnormailty, however

significant eccentric AR.  He declined aspirin because of
bleeding with his self-catheterization in the past.  He was
changed from diltiazem to metoprolol.  He had another episode of
chest/abd pain that appeared to be similar to his chronic "gas"
pain.  He was monitored for ischemia again but did not have an
increase in cardiac enymes or ekg changes.  Consider outpatient
stress test.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a 58yo woman with end stage multiple sclerosis
presenting with hypotension, tachycardia, fever, abdominal pain,
and mental status change which was diagnosed as urosepsis who is
s/p MICU stay, now on meropenem.
.
1. Fever, hypotension, and MS change: The patient's fever,
hypotension, and MS change were thought to be secondary to
urosepsis given her + UA. She had an elevated lactate on
admission and quickly became hypotensive. She was transferred to
the MICU, fluid resuscitated, and continued on
levofloxacin/vancomycin/metronidazole which was then changed to
Aztreonam given her allergy history when her UA came back
positive for proteus. A CXR was obtained and was concerning for
pneumonia vs atelectasis. However, given no h/o cough, sputum
production, chest pain, or SOB, or oxygen requirement, this
finding was attributed to atelectasis. The ddx also included
adrenal insufficiency since patient likely treated with steroids
for MS flares, and autonomic disregulation given h/o central
neurologic degenerative disease. A cortisol stimulation test was
preformed with a bump in cortisol level of only 6. However, at
this point the patient's hypotension had improved while on
empiric antibiotics. Urine and blood cx were negative. The
patient was hemodynamically stable with decreasing leukocytosis
and was transferred to the floor. She spiked with a bump in her
WBC ct and her coverage was broadened to meropenem and
vancomycin. She subsequently defervesced and her leukocytosis
resolved. She remained afebrile for > 48 hrs and vanco was
discontinued. She remained afebrile for an additional 48 hrs and
the patient was deemed well enough to be discharged on an
additional 7 day course of IV meropenem. The PICC line is ready
to use and may be pulled after completion of her 7 day course of
meropenem.
.
2. Tachycardia:  the patient remianed in sinus tachycardia
througout the duration of her hospitalization. The differential
included anxiety, pain, resolving hypotension/infection, and PE.
Given the patients abd pain, pain seemed a plausible etiology.
LENIs were obtained which were neg for PE and the pt did not
have an O2 requirement. Her tachycardia improved during the
duration of her hospitalization.
.
3. Abd pain:  The patient complained of persistent abdominal
pain throughout the course of her hospitalization. She had two
CT of abd/pelvis which were negative for obstruction, colitis,
pancreatitis, or abcess. Her LFTs were unremarkable.  She was
stooling well through her ostomy.  C diff was negative x 2. As
the patient had some skin breakdown around her ostomy site, this
was proposed to be the cause of her pain. She was also started
on Reglan with the thought that gastric motility may have been
affected, causing her abdominal pain and nausea. Also, the
epigastric location of her pain makes PUD a possible etiology.
Her PPI was increased to [**Hospital1 **] and her abdominal pain resolved
despite continued TTP upon exam.
.
4.  MS:  The patient has end stage MS. she was continued on
Copaxone and Baclofen per her outpt regimen.

History of Present Illness:
Patient is a 58 year old woman with a history of end-stage MS,
who is aphasic at baseline but can communicate through head
nods, presents with one day of fever, tachycardia (130s), and
mental status changes.  She was started on levofloxacin and
metronidazole at her nursing home for empiric coverage of
pneumonia on [**2195-3-16**].  By head nods, she denies chest pain,
fevers or chills, pain in her abdomen, nausea, vomiting, vaginal
itching or pain.
.
She was discharged on [**2195-3-7**] following admission with similar
symptoms (elevated lactate, elevated WBCs, fever, positive UA,
urine cultures with proteus, and hypotension) on which she was
found to have proteus urosepsis. She was discharged with seven
days of meropenem and sent out with a PICC line in place.  She
finished meropenem course four days prior to admission, but PICC
line was still in place.  Her only other complaint at that time
was pelvic/lower abdominal pain thought to be secondary to
peri-ostomy skin irritation and possible slowed gastric
motility. CT did not show any evidence of pathology. PPI was
increased to [**Hospital1 **].
.

pus from the catheter. UA was negative.  WBC was 14.1, and
lactate was initially 2.2.  She was admitted to the MICU due to
increased nursing needs.  Her vitals were 97.3, 99, 128/49, 17,

started on merepenem, ceftriaxone, vancomycin empirically for

dropped from 39 to 30.5.  Blood culture showed enterococcus,
with sensitivities pending, so linezolid was added for VRE

showed bibasilar atelectasis and could not rule out an
underlying consolidation.  Abdominal and pelvic CT showed no
acute inflammatory process.  Pelvic US was negative. Pelvic
swabs are pending. Urine and blood cultures are pending.

Brief Hospital Course:
ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 58 year old female with a history of
multiple sclerosis and aphasia, presents with one day history of
fever, tachycardia, mental status changes, and abdominal
tenderness following recent admission for urosepsis, treated
with meropenem and PICC line left in place four days after
completed course.
.
# FEVER: On admission, there was frank pus from her picc
catheter. WBC was elevated at 14.1. She was started on
vancomycin and ceftriaxone, although urinalysis did not indicate
urinary tract infection. Chest xray was not significantly
changed from her prior visit, which was thought to represent
atelectasis, though could not rule out pneumonia. She has
persistent lower abdominal and pelvic pain, and on CT was noted
to have intermediate density fluid in vagina and sludge and
gallbladder neck stone.  AST/ALT/AP/Tbili were all within
normal. Pelvic ultrasound was negative, examination and cultures
consistent with yeast, and she was treated with one dose of
fluconazole, and cultures for chlamydia and gonorrhea were
negative.  Blood cultures were positive for enterococcus,
initially empirically covered for vancomycin resistant
enterococcus.  She was initially started on linezolid for two
days, and was switched to vancomycin when cultures showed
sensitive to ampicillin, penicillin, and vancomycin.  She has a
penicillin allergy that causes limited rash, however per
ptatient may also have had shortness of breath with penicillin
in past.  TTE on [**2195-3-18**] did not reveal any vegetations.  TEE
was considered, but bacteremia was thought  most likely to be
transient, as no leaflet thickening on TTE.  Catheter tip
cultures were negative.  Surveillance cultures have been ordered
each day and continue to be negative since first set of
enterococcus.  Patient had a lesion (necrotic versus cellulitic)
on 1st right metatarsal, so ID recommended a  toe radiograph,
which shows an area of focal osteopenia, and no clear
osteomyelitis.  Swabs of the wound were positive for coagulase
positive staphylococcus and bacitracin ointment was recommended
for four days.  For the positive blood cultures, ID recommended
vancomycin for two weeks only.  A PICC was placed on day of
discharge so patient can be discharged to her home care facility
for the remainder of her course of vancomycin.  Please be sure
to pull her PICC line immediately after finishing the final dose
of vancomycin so as to decrease further risk of infection. WBC
continued to trend downwards for duration of admission, and
patient remained afebrile.
.
# MENTAL STATUS CHANGE: Patient presented with changes in mental
status, likely related to the onset of fever, pain, and
leukocytosis.  There is no history or evidence of trauma,
stroke, or hypoperfusion.  Mental status changes have resolved,
and patient is engaging appropriately, nodding in response to
questions.
.
# ABDOMINAL PAIN: Patient has mild tenderness to palpation
diffusely in her abdomen, likely chronic in nature.  On her last
admission she had abdominal pain, and two CTs of the abdomen and
pelvis were negative for obstruction.  Her LFTs were
unremarkable, and C diff was negative on two cultures.  Skin
breakdown around her ostomy site was noted and thought to be
contributing to her pain.  She had been started on Reglan with
the thought that gastric motility and PPI increased to [**Hospital1 **] for
gastroesophageal reflux disease. On this admission, CT shows
gallstones in neck and some sludge, but no elevation in biliary
or liver labs to indicate obstruction.  Pelvic exam was
negative, with positive cultures for yeast and she was given one
dose of fluconazole.  Transvaginal US was negative. No changes
in ostomy output.  She initially continued to groan and endorse
abdominal pain, with diffuse mild tenderness to palpation
throughout abdomen.  On [**2195-3-21**] she was much more comfortable
and had stopped groaning.  On [**2195-3-23**] she no longer complained
of abdominal pain.
.
# HEEL AND TOE WOUNDS: Patient has erythematous patch on back of
right ankle, consistent with stage 1 ulcer.  Podiatry was
consulted and recommended cleaning with bacitracin dressings.
ID was concerned for right first metacarpal toe lesion, so
ordered toe scan, as above, which showed focal area of
osteopenia; no MRI was thought necessary. The patient should
follow up with podiatry as an outpatient in about two weeks
after discharge.
.
# MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS: We contineudthe patient's usual outpatient
neurologic medications including valproic acid, copaxone and
baclofen.
.
# DEPRESSION: Patient has depression at baseline. We continued
her home dose of Amitriptyline without event.
.
# FEN: At baseline, patient is fed through g-tube s/p colectomy
[**11-7**].  She was aggressively rehydrated in the ED and had stable
systolic blood pressures in the 110-120s.  We continued her
usual tube feeds of Probalance full strength at 55cc/hr. She is
otherwise NPO. We continued her calcium and vitamin D as well as
her daily multivitamin.
.
# ACCESS: L PICC placed on day of discharge. This should be
pulled immediately after last dose of vancomycin is finished.
.
# CODE: Confirmed DNR/DNI status.
.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  In the preoperative holding area, the
patient was noted to have an increased swelling in her leg
with 4+ pitting edema relatively equal bilaterally.  She was
also noted to have a 1+ posterior tibial pulse bilaterally.
She had no rash and no pain on palpation of her posterior
leg.  In addition, she was clear to auscultation bilaterally.
She had a regular rate and rhythm and her abdomen was soft
with slight right lower quadrant tenderness but nondistended.
The patient reported that the swelling had increased over the
last 24 hours.  It was decided to take her to the operating
room for her restorative proctocolectomy.

On [**2181-12-25**], the patient underwent a proctocolectomy and
diverting ileostomy.  The patient tolerated the procedure
well; please see dictated operative note for further details.
Postoperatively the patient was placed on cefazolin and
Flagyl perioperatively.  She was notably tachycardic with a
heart rate of 122 and it ranged from 120 to 130 but she
complained of no shortness of breath or chest pain.  Her
blood pressure was 112/84 and she had good urine output of
295 cc over two hours.  The patient had a JP drain placed
intraoperatively which put out 150 cc of serosanguineous
fluids.

An EKG was obtained which showed sinus tachycardia at 130
beats-per-minute with no ischemic changes and normal access
and progression.  As the patient was in pain that she rated 6
out of 10, it was thought that her tachycardia was most
likely secondary to this pain.

On postoperative day one, the patient continued to be in pain
that she rated 8 out of 10 that was located deep in her right
lower quadrant.  She had no chest pain, no shortness of
breath, or other complaints.  Her heart rate continued to be
elevated in the range of 127 to 134 with a blood pressure of
112/70.  She produced 280 cc of urine output over eight hours
and she was still thought to have tachycardia secondary to
her pain.  Her morphine PCA was adjusted.  However, she was
also noted to have 3+ pitting edema bilaterally in her lower
extremities but no tenderness. A lower extremity ultrasound
was therefore obtained to rule out DVTs.

The ultrasound showed on the right noncompressibility of the
popliteal, posterior tibial, and peroneal veins consistent
with DVTs.  There were no DVTs noted on the left.  The
patient was therefore begun on a heparin drip and her PTT was
measured serially and the drip was adjusted to maintain the
PTT in the range of 60 to 80.

On the morning of postoperative day two, the patient
consented to be tachycardic and had an oxygen saturation of
91 to 95% on a 40% face mask.  Her urine output was good and
based on the Doppler ultrasound it was assumed that the
patient had a pulmonary embolus leading to her tachycardia
and poor oxygen saturations.  To verify this, a chest CTA was
obtained.

It showed multiple filling defects in essentially all of the
lobar pulmonary arteries consistent with extensive pulmonary
embolus.  However, the central, main, and right and left
pulmonary arteries were free of thrombus.

On postoperative day two, the patient's pain was decreased
with only mild incisional tenderness on her morphine PCA.
The patient was placed on a higher dose of steroids
surrounding her operation which were subsequently tapered to
her preoperative steroid dose over three to four days
postoperatively.

On the evening of postoperative day two, the patient was
noted to have a change in mental status.  She was arousable
and responsive but could not remember where she was or why
she was here.  She also could not stay awake and would fall
asleep in the middle of questions.  Because of the patient's
bilateral pulmonary emboli and her change in mental status,
it was decided to send her to the Intensive Care Unit for
closer monitoring and to do a mental status work-up.

The patient received a chest x-ray, an arterial blood gas, an
EKG, a complete set of lytes.  The patient also was ruled out
for a MI with cardiac enzymes.  Ultimately, there was no
source found for her change in mental status.  Her mental
status slowly cleared over the course of the next two days
and she was transferred back to the floor.  However, she
received 2 U of packed red blood cells for a hematocrit that
reached a low of 24.9 on postoperative day three.  The
patient continued on her heparin drip with a goal PT in the
range of 60 to 80.

On postoperative day five, the patient was started on a sip
diet which was slowly advanced over the next several days.
The patient was also started on low-pressor for her
continuing tachycardia that ranged up into the 120s and blood
pressure that ranged up into the 150s to 160s.

On postoperative day six, the patient's JP output began to
increase and was notably sanguinous.  Hematocrit was drawn
and remained in the range of 29 to 30 however, on
postoperative day seven, the patient's hematocrit reached a
low of 26.8 and she was consequently transfused with 2 U of
packed red blood cells bringing her hematocrit up to 32.3.
Because of the patient's apparent rebleeding
intraabdominally, it was decided to try to place [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 260**]
filter in her inferior vena cava.

The consult was obtained however the cardiac catheterization
laboratory was unable to place the filter secondary to a
sclerotic inferior vena cava below the renal vein with a
non-mobile thrombus in the lower aspect of the inferior vena
cava just below the renal veins.  The patient was noted to
have extensive collaterals in the pelvis and the findings
suggested a recanalized clot in the inferior vena cava.  It
was suggested that the patient receive a MRV to definitively
diagnose the patient's condition.  Because of the inability
to place the [**Location (un) 260**] filter, the patient was continued on
her heparin drip and her hematocrit and JP output were
closely monitored.  The patient however did not require any
further transfusions and her JP was pulled out on
postoperative day nine.  Also on postoperative day nine, the
patient was started on Coumadin in an attempt to transition
her to Coumadin for discharge.  Her INR over the course of
the next several days rose to a super-therapeutic level of
4.1 despite lower and lower doses of Coumadin.  Her heparin
drip was stopped and while the patient was eating, drinking,
walking, and her pain was well-controlled, she was kept
in-house until her PTT level was brought into the therapeutic
range.  This was achieved on postoperative day fifteen when
the patient's PTT level fell to 2.6.

In the intervening period, the only other significant finding
was that the ostomy was somewhat retracted as some of the
lower sutures had pulled out.  The plan was to follow the
retraction of the ostomy as an outpatient.

Also of note, the patient had burning on urination several
days prior to her discharge.  A urinalysis and a urine
culture was obtained which showed a proteus infection
sensitive to levofloxacin.  The patient was therefore started
on a five-day-course of levofloxacin to be completed as an
outpatient.

Brief Hospital Course:
ALCOHOL WITHDRAWAL:

Mr. [**Known lastname 98193**] is a 66 y.o. man with a history significant for
longstanding etoh abuse with past episodes of DTs; relapsing MS
x30 years, wheelchair-bound with a neurogenic bladder and
history of multi-drug resistant urinary tract infections. More
recently, Mr. [**Known lastname 98193**] has presented to the [**Hospital1 **] ED three times in
the past month, twice admitted for treatment of withdrawal via
CIWA scale benzodiazepene administration. The most recent
admission was on [**7-24**], and at that time he was evaluated by
psychiatry who felt that his symptoms were also consistent with
considerable anxiety. He was discharged home on [**2130-7-31**] with
antibiotics for E. coli urinary tract infection.

On [**8-13**] he presented again to the ED complaining of
tremulousness, racing heartbeat, flushing, and diaphoresis. By
report in the ED he also had some auditory hallucinations. He
was given klonopin 1mg and valium 1mg. Subsequent tox screen was
negative for etoh, positive for benzos only. CIWA scale was 30+.
On admission to the floor he had two episodes of ??????shaking??????
described by the sitter. He remained conscious and oriented
during these episodes, which the sitter described as general
shaking of his arms and legs. These episodes were presumed to be
seizures and treated with a total of 40mg of IV valium, 10 mg of
po valium with a CIWA scale persistently >25. His exam has been
otherwise benign on the floor, VSS without fevers, tachycardia
~100s.  Patient transferred to [**Hospital Unit Name 153**] for continued monitoring.

Patient did well and was returned to the floor and required no
further benzodiazepines per CIWA score <10 by [**2130-8-14**].  He
remained sleepy for several days due to the long half-life and
large quantity of benzodiazepines administered to treat alcohol
withdrawal.

As patient's mental status improved, he strongly endorsed a
desire for rehabilitation and interest in quitting drinking.  He
was very interested in seeking institutional rehabilitation.

URINARY TRACT INFECTION:

On [**2130-8-13**], patient complained of "bladder spasms" which he
stated was consistent with previous episodes of urinary tract
infections.  Urinalysis at the time revealed
bacteria and white cells in urine.  Patient was treated with
ceftriaxone and then switched to cephalexin PO in anticipation
of discharge to continue treatment as outpatient.

EPISODE OF UNRESPONSIVENESS:

On hospital day 5, patient was found by nursing staff to be
unresponsive, with "pinpoint pupils".  Patient was given Narcan
with good effect, and patient was roused for several minutes,
but urine toxicology revealed no evidence of narcotics (only
positive for benzodiazepines).  Patient was transferred to the
ICU for frequent neuro checks overnight, although patient had no
loss of bowel continence and no evidence of mucous membrane or
tongue trauma.  Patient was deemed stable on hospital day 6 and
returned to the floor.  EEG revealed changes consistent with
mild toxic-metabolic encephalopathy.  Neuro consult did not feel
that the episode was consistent with a seizure, as again,
patient stated that he remembered the episode and was conscious
for the entire duration of the event (but could not respond).
Neuro will follow patient in ten days following discharge.

PARAPHIMOSIS:

On hospital day 7, patient was noted to have significant edema
of the foreskin, consistent with paraphimosis without ischemia.
The foreskin was easily reduced and edema was treated with
compression and ice with good effect.  However, on hospital day
9, patient was found to have purulent urethral discharge
(negative urinalysis) and caking on the glans underneath the
foreskin.  Discharge was sent for gram stain and culture
(including yeast and fungus), and will be followed up after
discharge.  Patient was restarted on Keflex for 7 days along
with a miconazole topical powder for empiric treatment of the
discharge.

DISPOSITION:

Patient was very interested in institutional alcoholic
rehabilitation throughout his hospital stay and felt very
strongly that he could not continue in this pattern of recurrent
abuse and withdrawal.  Patient was deemed to be stable for
discharge on hospital day 9.

Brief Hospital Course:
# Pneumonia:  Patient was on rocephin at the nursing home x 3
days without improvement.  He was admitted to ICU for
noninvasive positive pressure ventilation and antibiotics were
expanded to vancomycin, zosyn, and azithromycin.  Patient has
steadily improved and now is stable on room air and remains
afebrile.  Given sputum results, plan to continue vancomycin x
14 days and patient will also complete a 14 day course of
levofloxacin for treatment of his pneumonia.  He received chest
PT while in house but is currently coughing up his sputum well.
He is on scheduled nebs to optimize his airways in the setting
of his resolving pneumonia.
.
# Hypotension:  Patient's blood pressure low on admission but
improved with IVF boluses.  He did not require pressors and has
remained hemodynamically stable for days without additional
boluses.  Cortrysn stim test in the ICU showed an appropriate
response.
.
# Altered mental status:  Patient was lethargic on admission.
Head CT was unremarkable and mental status improved considerably
with treatment of his pneumonia.  TSH, folate, B12, RPR, and
TFTs were all unremarkable.
.
# MS: Per [**Year (4 digits) 802**], patient is too weak to walk at baseline.
Recommend reevaluation at nursing home for modified wheelchair
to improve mobility.  He was continued on his home doses of
baclofen and neurontin.
.
# Depression: Mood stable.  Patient continued on his home
trazodone + celexa.
.
# Anemia: Hematocrit stable.  Patient continued on his home
iron.
.
# HTN: Patient continued on his home beta blocker in house.
Plan to restart norvasc at the nursing home.
.
# FEN: While in house, patient had a swallow evaluation to rule
out overt aspiration.  No overt aspiration on bedside
evaluation.  Patient is on a ground diet with thin liquids.
Recommend all his meds be administered in pureed form.
.
# PPX: home PPI, SQ heparin, wound consult was obtained for
wound care
.
# DNR/DNI
.
# Dispo: patient discharged back to his nursing home

facility, he was treated with with Meropenem and [**Known lastname **].
His foley was replaced.  He became afebrile, and his bandemia
resolved and he had no further seizure activity.  Presumably his
presentation was secondary to [**Known lastname 27285**] tract infection in the
setting of chronic foley. Patient hemodynamically normalized on

urine output improved.  On [**5-13**], he was transferred from the ICU

and given no prior history of MRSA in urine cultures, [**Month/Year (2) **]

History of Present Illness:
Mr. [**Known lastname 99500**] is a 62 year old gentleman with history of multiple
sclerosis, [**Known lastname 862**] disorder, dementia, and chronic indwelling
foley with recurrent UTIs (including ESBL klebsiella) presented
from his nursing home with altered mental status.  In
communication with his PCP and [**Name9 (PRE) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **], the patient's
baseline mental status is alert and talkative(occasionally
rambling), but he became lethargic and somnolent beginning the
day prior to admission at the nursing home.  He reportedly had a
U/A and culture sent 3 days prior to admission which revealed
VRE (reportedly only sensitive to macrodantin) and proteus.  His
nurse practitioner felt he was likely colonized with VRE and
proteus was sensitive to ampicillin, thus he was started on
ampicillin at that time.  At that time, he was also felt to be
fecally obstructed, so he was given a fleets enema to which he
responded well.  On the evening prior to admission, in addition
to his change in mental status, he was found to be tachycardic
to the low 100s.  He was, however, afebrile and systolic blood
pressures were consistently in the 100s-120s.  His mental status
declined overnight at the nursing home and he was transferred to
the ED for further evaluation and management.
.
In the ED, his initial vitals revealed: HR 107 BP 98/28 RR 14
O2sat 100%on NRB-->RA; no temperature was recorded.  He was
noted to have abdominal discomfort and suprapubic fullness.  His
foley was found to be obstructed and when resolved, was noted to
drain frank pus from his bladder.  Labs demonstrated WBC count
of 27 with 16% bandemia and an elevated lactate to 10.5 which
decreased to 8.6 with IV fluids.  A CT abd/pelvis was obtained
to rule out bowel ischemia and surgery was consulted.  CT
abd/pelvis did not reveal ischemia of the gut, but did note
thickening of perirectal and sigmoid wall believed consistent
with chronic laxative use vs. infectious/inflammatory etiology.
A CXR showed a retrocardiac opacity thought to represent
atelectasis vs. consolidation.  Blood and urine cultures were
sent and he received vanco/levofloxacin/flagyl.  Given his
altered mental status, a head CT was obtained which was negative
for hemorrhage and mass effect.
.
Although it is not clearly documented, he reportedly received 7L
NS IV fluid resuscitation.  His ED course was complicated by
multiple attempts at central venous access and he was initially
started on peripheral dopamine to maintain his blood pressure.
A right IJ was then placed and MAPs remained in the low 50s so
levophed was started in addition to dopamine prior to his
transfer to the ICU.
.

PROCEDURE/FINDINGS: A prominent dilated gallbladder with a few
intraluminal shadowing stones is appreciated. After explaining
the risks and benefits of the procedure, informed written
consent was obtained. The patient was placed supine on the table
and a timeout was performed to confirm patient name, location,
and procedure. The patient was prepped and draped in the usual
sterile fashion and 1% lidocaine was used for local anesthesia.
Under constant ultrasound guidance, [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 4300**] needle was
percutaneously placed into the gallbladder. An 8 French dilator
was used and an 8 French pigtail catheter was subsequently
threaded into the gallbladder lumen. 100 cc of dark bile was
aspirated and sent for culture.

The patient tolerated the procedure well and there were no
complications. Mild sedation was used including 25 mcg of
Fentanyl IV. The attending, Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] [**Name (STitle) **], was present and
performed the entire procedure.

Post-procedure orders were placed in CareWeb.

IMPRESSION: Successful ultrasound-guided drainage and catheter
placement within gallbladder.

Brief Hospital Course:
#Urosepsis - ICU course: On presentation the patient met
criteria for SIRS and sepsis: WBC of 27, tachycardic and a
source of infection, thought to be most likely urosepsis given
frank pus drainage from the bladder, history of recurrent
infections and his foley found to be obstructed. In review of
past culture data, UTIs in the past have grown pansensitive E.
Coli and ESBL resistant klebsiella previously sensitive to
meropenem, imipenem, zosyn. Per nursing home report, urine
cultures from 3 days PTA grew VRE (sensitivities unknown) and
proteus. He has also had multiple wound swabs that revealed MRSA
and pseudomonas, thus, it was thought also reasonable to
initially cover for MRSA. His wounds, however, do not appear to
be infected and were thought unlikely to be a contributing
source of sepsis. The CT of the abdomen did not appear
consistent with bowel ischemia, but the patient was initially
started on flagyl given colonic thickening. Upon arrival to the
ICU, his CVP initially was [**7-4**], on a dopamine, levophed and
vasopressin drip. A cortisol stimulation test was negative for
adrenal suppression. With input from ID, the patient was started
on meropenem and daptomycin and flagyl was continued. We were
able to wean the dopamine to off on day 1 in the ICU, and
levophed and vasopressin were weaned on day 2. CVP was
maintained between [**7-5**] with 500cc LR boluses on day 3, and the
patient did not require additional boluses on day 4. By day 4 he
was assessed as stable, recovering from the septic picture, and
fit to be called out to the floor. Blood cultures grew GNRs
which were identified as proteus on day 3 (sensitivities above)
([**2171-6-27**]). Based on sensitivities, IV meropenem was continued and
Daptomycin was discontinued.

On the floor, meropenem was continued. However he started having
fevers again and hence flagyl was restarted. Multiple tests done
to identify source of infection - MRI spine - no abscess or
osteomyelitis, ECHO no IE. Cultures neg. no C diff. No PICC
infection, Foley changed. ID was consulted and CT abd, HIDA done
that confirmed acute cholecystitis. Surgery deemed the patient a
poor surgical candidate and hence a cholesystostomy tube was
placed by IR. Abx were changed to aztreonam. WBC scan prior to
dc was normal. Patient finally remained afebrile for > 4 days
prior to discharge. He is to complete a 2 wk course of IV
aztreonam - day 1 [**2171-7-15**]. Flagyl was stopped after about a 3 wk
course. Patient advised a follow up appointment with Dr
[**Last Name (STitle) 4020**] from infectious disease in 2 weeks as well as on
[**2171-7-26**] - patient should get a CBC, chem 7 for monitoring and
results to be faxed as stated below to Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 4020**] who will
check the results. Brief Ca work up as a fever source (PSA,
SPEP, UPEP) normal.

Acute retention of urine was resolved after foley was placed.
Patient may be advised if an SPC is desired to see Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 770**] in
clinic given recurrent UTIs and [**Last Name (STitle) 27285**] obstruction due to MS.

[**Last Name (STitle) **] disorder: The patient had a tonic-clonic [**Last Name (STitle) 862**] on the
first night of admission, that resolved spontaneously within 2
minutes. This was likely exacerbated by his septic state. His
phenytoin and carbamazapine levels were normal. He has been
[**Last Name (STitle) 862**]-free since then. He was maintained on his outpatient
doses of phenytoin and carbamazapine.

After a speech and swallow evaluation, his diet was advanced as
below. Regular diet per second swallow evaluation.

Acute renal failure: Baseline creatinine is 0.4-0.9. Initial
bump in creatinine most likely was secondary to obstruction, but
also given hemoconcentration and response to fluids, appeared to
be prerenal as well. Given frank pus from bladder, ascending b/l
pyelo was a concern, but CT A/P, albeit without contrast, did
not show evidence of this. Creatinine back to baseline 2-3 days
after initiation of volume resuscitation.

Coagulopathy: INR was elevated to 1.5, then 2.2 in the absence
of blood thinning agents. Given his poor nutritional status, may
be a result of vit K deficiency, but certainly was concerning in
the setting of sepsis. Platelet count was normal. D-dimer
decreasing steadily, stable fibrinogen reassuring that DIC is
unlikely.
- INR normalized with 3 daily doses of vitamin K
.
# EKG changes: T wave inversions in septal leads most likely
reflected lead placement, but new from most recent EKG. MB index
negative x2. Ruled out for MI by cardiac enzymes, cardiac
ischemia was unlikely. No events were seen on tele during the
ICU stay. Patient remained CP free.
.
# Elevated LFTs: Initially the process could be related to the
sepsis. However, later he did have acute cholecystitis refer
above. LFT continued to trend down during admission. Normal at
discharge.

# Pancreatitis attributed to Ileus from MS - developed slight
elevation of lipase in setting of ileus attributed to MS.  Made
NPO for two days.  Repeat CT abdomen without evidence of
pancreatitis, but GB distension and edema with stones. Diagnosed
with cholecystitis as above. Golytely given 2 L per day for two
days with tap water enemas twice daily for two days. Ileus was
aggressively treated and resolved. No acute mech bowel
obstruction was noted.

# Facial rash consistent with fungal infection - stated
miconazole cream.

# Noted anemia and thrombocytosis both of which were stable at
discharge. Please recheck another CBC in a month to be deferred
to the PCP.

Patient has a new PICC dated [**2171-7-22**] and to complete aztreonam
as above. To make appt with IR for biliay drain removal as
below. ID, surgery to follow up.
